segments.text: Of course, that process had left me physically and intellectually tired.
And so when I met this candidate, Dr. Dean Corrigan, C-O-R-R-I-G-A-N, then the Dean of Education at the University of Maryland,
I was feeling that he had really better do a good job or that I might discount his capability quickly.
By that point in my search committee experience,
I tried to begin each interviewee's campus visit with a, quote, introductory session, quote, in which I, as the search committee chairman, would introduce the visitor at a session
to which all members of the college faculty had been invited.
They would have been provided with a brief resume of the newcomer.
And I would then introduce the individual who would be asked to
describe background of experience, and then discuss for the faculty what they thought were the major issues facing the general field
in this case, of education.
Also, we agreed in advance that the questions would not be informational quiz questions, but would be general in nature, trying to obtain
a broader view of the speaker's attitudes and feelings.
Paragraph.
Within a few minutes after Dean Corrigan began his presentation, my mind and spirit was quickly awakened and alert.
He seemed soon, he was the almost unanimous choice of everyone.
And he came to A&M and fulfilled the expectations of so many people.
Paragraph.
Back in the early Calhoun and Williams days, one of the brief efforts which proved to be very productive was to select a few highly competent and young alumni
who seemed to offer great promise for future success.
These youngsters would serve as aides to the president, the vice president for academic affairs, and also work in Austin.
The success of such an effort can be demonstrated when the identity of these men is mentioned as Kent Caperton, who had been president of the student body under Dr. Williams.
and would later be an outstanding state senator and lawyer.
He assisted Dr. Williams.
Dave Mayfield, a product of architecture, who would go on to great success in his profession, served with
those of us in academic affairs.
And at this point, I cannot remember the young man from Hamilton, Texas, who was one of the key members of the A&M staff in Austin, serving as a sort of intern lobbyist, lobbyist
in turn.
The success of these three not only in what they did but what they became leads me now to wonder why didn't we continue that practice in future years
because the cost, the financial cost was comparatively modest and the returns in future capability of the individuals and meaningful benefit to the institution was remarkably substantial.

During those years, during the Williams years, the president's office was on the second floor at the south end of what we call the System Building, the magnificent white marble structure facing east toward Texas Avenue.
As president of both the university, of both Texas A&M University and the A&M system, Earl Rudder and Jack Williams could and did make decisions without having to send them up
to another level of bureaucratic delay, review, and delay.
The bureaucracy in numbers, layers, and cost in time and personnel
was quite modest.
The effectiveness was even more impressive.
Both Rudder and Williams were able to move the institution forward in every way there could be measurement.
including enrollment, quality of student body, research volume in dollars, and significance, as well as national image and reputation.
All of us were more and more proud to be a part of Texas A&M.
Paragraph.
As dean of faculties, one of my responsibilities was to attend coordinating board meetings in Austin.
That agency was responsible for
the coordination quote of all public higher education in the state.
Thus, that group of gubernatorial appointees have the authority to authorize all
academic areas of study, organizational pattern, and enrollment quality of each institution.
Thus, it was they who could control
the general direction of every public campus in Texas, even at the level superior to the regions.
The opportunity for me to attend coordinating board meetings was very meaningful in terms of my
understanding of higher education and future capability to relate to governing boards and state agencies.
I believe that the Coordinating Board included perhaps 21 members, 18 to 21, something like that.
A broad variety, geographic, in terms of geographic
fake background, opinions, attitudes, et cetera.
This is a note to the typist.
At this point I'm in San Marcos and just realized that I missed a turn way back down the road and gone a bit out of my way.
So we'll get back on the track though of the coordinating board.
As the A&M administrator who attended all coordinating board meetings,
I became the accompanist for all new A&M degree program requests and or organizational changes and gradually
became well acquainted with the key coordinating board staff members.
Particularly Ken, whose name I cannot think of, who would for a long time be
the Commissioner of Higher Education for Texas.
The most important of these program changes at A&M began one morning with a call from Jack Williams.
Dr. Calhoun was out of town, and as I recall, I answered the phone and came to instant attitudinal attention when Dr. Williams
Ask directed when Ernie and me.
To come over to his office as soon as we could get there.
We hurry across the street.
Wondering what?
The new task might be.
And we're greeted.
With a quick smile.
and a truly challenging statement.
Quote, I don't think you guys can do this, Dash, but I want here on my desk by this time next week all of the paperwork it will take for us to be able
to request officially, through the Board of Regents, Coordinating Board, and the legislature, authority to offer degrees in medicine and law at Texas A&M.
Quickly, as we returned, Dick and I quickly divided the task with medicine for him and law for me.
And we worked tirelessly with the always determined and capable staff.
and succeeded in reaching the assigned goal one day before the deadline which Dr. Williams had set.
As the process began to evolve,
all around the state, the other institutions that offered law and or medicine, whether public or private, began to speak out in loud opposition to any A&M effort in that direction.
Nevertheless, we proceeded and the regents approved the request as we tried to go forward.
In regard to law, the only ally we were able to identify was the great Houston lawyer, Leon, and I can't think of his last name, a graduate of Baylor who had a most admirable career
including having served on the staff of the Nuremberg trials following World War II.
Probably because of his influence, A&M was offered
the South Texas College of Law.
I understood that A&M was offered the South Texas College of Law with almost no strings attached except that it would never be able to offer any law courses
outside Harris County.
Dr. Williams declined that restriction because he wanted law and medicine as a part of the process to broaden A&M's academic view and influence.
Meanwhile, I became a junior partner in Winerdi's effort on medicine.
In that process, we happened to stumble onto a minor, what was possibly thought of as a minor addition
to an act of the Texas legislature in 1943.
That amendment gave legal authorization to a medical school, quote,
Affiliated with the Scott and White Clinic in Temple, TX.
Quote.
If it was attached.
To a public institution.
After that discovery.
Hey.
Maroon and white.
Lit.
Caravan quickly headed to Scott and White.
And received a warm.
Reading.
In addition, Dr. Williams hoped to make the A&M Medical Program a three-way partnership by including both Scott and Point in Temple and the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston.
And the lawyer's name I was trying to think of
a moment ago was Leon Jaworski, J-A-W-O-R-S-K-I.
Dr. Williams Paragraph was well acquainted with the great heart surgeon, whose name escapes me right now, who then headed Baylor Medicine.
And so for a number of months,
we proceeded with that tripartite plan.
Our application could not be stopped at the state level because legal authorization had already been given by the 1943 legislation.
It did not include funding and the other medical
groups in Texas joined in opposing an additional competitor for state dollars.
Meanwhile, our application to the American Medical Association's accrediting group
seemed to stall without any explanation.
Then one day I happened to stumble onto the fact that that group was headed by an individual who had been
terminated for some unknown reason by the Baylor administration a number of years earlier.
That led the A&M planners to assume that we would not have any success with the American Medical Association's bureaucracy unless we
terminated the Baylor link.
Paragraph thus, with only Scott and White and A&M as partners, the plan was approved without delay.
And we proceeded to dream of a medical school

where the students would attend their first two years of study at college station and the two latter two clinical years in temple at the splendid scott and serve at the splendid scott and white hospital the emphasis
in the A&M proposal was on broad service, family medicine, and community effort.
The plan would be for every student to begin making rounds in Brazos County with medical practitioners
the first day of the student's first year of medical school.
Then in Temple, they would be in one of the most innovative medical, most innovative hospitals in the United States.
Hold on, typist.
I'm having to consult my roadmap here.
One of the key moments in the search for funding came one day in College Station.
when the, when Tiger Teague, when Olin Teague, the Tiger to his A&M classmates and countless others who knew him as a World War II hero,
and a determined congressional leader joined the group.
In some manner of discussion, he noted that he wished he could help A&M get some funding
but that he didn't know anything he could do as a member of Congress.

Yet he wished as chairman of the Veterans Affairs Committee that something could be done to get medical schools to help Veterans Administration hospitals that were because they were beginning to suffer.
a shortage of medical practitioners.
I quickly broke in by mentioning that there was a veteran's hospital across the street from Scott and White up in Temple.
Quietly, Mr. Teague smiled, pulled out a note card from his pocket,
and wrote something on that page.
Perhaps
